title: The Politics of Atopic Dermatitis (Dry Skin? Oily Skin? Combination?)

content: Conversations surrounding different skin types and the characteristics that made mine deviate from someone without eczema never used medical terminology. No one referred to this skin condition to me as atopic dermatitis – not even my eight previous dermatologists. I did, however, reach an understanding from the easy ways we as a community decided to categorize the different states of skin. Dry, oily, and combination.

My understanding was something that can be described as “vibes only.” I know that dry skin means you have to moisturize more; oily skin makes your face more shiny in comparison; combination skin, given the obvious context, is a mixture between the two. One would think there are countless factors that would make sorting an individual into such a few categories a complicated process. Three choices don't account for how your skin might adapt to the winter or the weather of different places while you travel, or the ingredients that work better for your lotion.

But three choices also help you narrow down all of those if s and but s. When learning to deal with eczema, a lot of the tips and tricks dedicated to people with dry skin helped me more than hacks intended for people with oily skin. It's all trial and error. A personalization of trying until you find the right ways to treat your skin.

content: In the vein of giving more meaning to vibes (it's one of my New Year's resolutions), I want to narrow down the why of these skin types. Let's go in order of how I referenced them below:
Vibe: Dry skin means you have to moisturize more.
Meaning: “Dry skin develops when your skin loses water too quickly and becomes dehydrated. Age, medical history, the season, and bathing habits may lead to dry skin.”
Vibe: Oily skin makes your face shinier.
Meaning: “Oily skin is caused by an over-secretion of sebum, an oily substance our skin needs to function properly. Too much of this sebum can cause acne and too little can cause dry, cracked skin.”
Vibe: Combination skin has traits of both dry and oily.

content: Meaning: True to its inferred definition, combination skin features two or more skin types, but the main distinction is that “the condition of your skin may fluctuate between seasons. Typically, the combination skin type is characterized by dry, flaking skin on the cheeks, while excessive oil and shine appear on other areas of the face.”

content: While its common characteristics are what allow people to be diagnosed with eczema, I’ve also realized that atopic dermatitis does not look the same on every person. It certainly presents itself differently on people with darker skin. It can be irritating and frustrating in different ways for different people. Just a few years ago, it caused me a lot of pain, but now it's something I’m able to manage – with new products and medication and a better quality of living.

The reason why I find it so important to understand the meaning of these words and definitions and conditions is because as silly as it sounds, the sorting and categorizing help lead you to the solutions best suited for your skin.
Skin care is a holistic job – working internally and externally toward the same goal. There's meaning to that, don't you think?
